This charge the fair Phillida gave,</br>"Ye virgins attend on my bier,</br>Let cowslips in spring deck my grave,</br>And wet them sometimes with a tear.
"This duty is due to my youth,</br>If nought to my friendship ye owe;</br>Were my days to be longer, my truth,</br>Perhaps, ye more fully would know.
"But — tokens of kindness receive:</br>My sheep crook O Daphne's for thee;</br>And to my lov'd Phoebe I give</br>Each ribbon belonging to me.
"O Collin!  my lamb and my ewe</br>Unto thy fond care I resign;</br>Fond care still I'm sure thou wilt shew,</br>When remembrance says they were mine.
"But have I no better to give,</br>No better, before I depart!</br>Yes!  yes, dearest shepherd!  receive</br>Whatever was thine — my fond heart!
"And, if 'tis permitted the bless'd</br>To wander from regions above,</br>Each night will I guard thee in rest,</br>Each day will I visit my love!"
These were the last words which she said,</br>Ere her eyes their sweet lustre deny'd,</br>Ere the roses on her cheeks did fade,</br>Ere she fainted, and sighed, and — dy'd!
When she dy'd, then the flow'ret was lost,</br>Whose blooming inamour'd each eye!</br>Whose sweetness was Nature's fond boast,</br>And none ever dar'd to deny!
As the village attended her bier,</br>And saw the sod plac'd on her breast,</br>What eye then denied a tear?</br>What tongue but her praises express'd?
If truth is of worth to mankind,</br>If innocence still doth invite,</br>If happiness sweetness of mind,</br>And constancy, ever delight;
If wisdom still pleasing appears,</br>Or wit, when good natur'dly dress'd;</br>Well Phillida won all their tears,</br>She won all the praise they express'd!
If shepherds such sorrows did shew,</br>O Collin!  what griefs should be thine?</br>Her friendship, 'tis true, they did know,</br>But — all her best wishes were mine!
Ye woodbines that run to decay,</br>In yonder imbowering grove!</br>O!  witness this truth in my lay,</br>I bury'd all joy with my love.
Bear witness, thou once-charming bow'r,</br>On which I employ'd all my art,</br>In which I oft cheated an hour,</br>With Phillida, Queen of my heart.
Bear witness, my herds, as ye stray,</br>And pinching necessity prove,</br>I sigh and I weep the long day,</br>Since I was bereft of my love.
And witness, thou lamb and thou ewe,</br>That feed of the best from my hands,</br>To nothing attention I shew,</br>Save to my dear Phillida's commands.
Save to the gay myrtles I dress,</br>That grow in the sod o'er the fair,</br>Whose sweets shall her virtues express,</br>Whose verdure my truth shall declare.
But — night has o'erta'en my complaint;</br>The shepherds retire to their rest,—</br>Attend!  O attend, my dear saint!</br>In vision O let me be bless'd!
Present thee in thy wonted charms!</br>Appear, as thou us'd to be — gay!</br>Then let me depart in thy arms,</br>And waft me!  O waft me away!</br>
